doc.field: vacation church germany europe köln colognecathedral

Guests may visit the Cologne Cathedral daily at no cost. However, there is a charge to go up into the south tower which has a viewing platform at a height of 97 meters (318ft). Make sure you're ready for a climb of 509 steps as there is no elevator in the tower. including the 24 tons heavy Petersglocke (St. Peter's Bell), cast in 1923.

Nikon and Fuji are the last things you expect to see when you visit Köln (Cologne) for its historic cathedral. Yet, these camera stores are the first things that greet you as you walk towards the cathedral entrance, as these shops are set against one of the cathedral walls. You can see the Köln (Cologne) cathedral itself towering behind the commercial establishments. The Köln cathedral is almost adjoining the Hauptbahnhof, it's just a few minutes walk. It was freezing cold and was beginning to rain. (Jan. 2008)

Cologne's magnificent Cathedral is the most renowned landmark in the city and serves as the seat of the Archbishop of Cologne. It is one of the largest churches in the world and for some time the cathedral even held the title of the world's tallest building. (Jan. 2008)
canon ef1635mmf28liiusm 1635 canoneos5dmarkii germany cologne cathedral köln dom hdr f5

At the east end of the Köln cathedral stands its greatest treasure, the Shrine of the Kings. It's a wooden casket containing the relics of the Magi,and is encased in a golden case, studded with jewels. Work on the Shrine of Kings casket was started in 1180, ad it took almost fifty years to complete. (Jan. 2008)
The main entrance to the Cologne Cathedral (May 2012).
Cathedral interior, looking towards the east end. (Jan. 2008)
This life size model was put in place to commemorate the finishing of the Cathedral in 1880
Model Finial in front of Cologne Cathedral

Also noteworthy at the Köln cathedral are the large stained glass windows, which cover an area of about 10,000 sq meters (110,000 sq feet) and allow plenty of natural light to enter the building. The oldest window in the cathedral - known as the Älteres Bibelfenster (Old Bible Window) - is in the chapel of the Three Magi. (Jan. 2008)

A view of the cathedral interior from where I was sitting. This is I think a view of the south nave. Too bad about the limitation of the cigarette pack sized Fuji Z2 camera. It wasn't suited to low light photography. (Jan. 2008)
Signage in the Köln cathedral crypt shows the various cardinals bishops and their tenure. The Köln cathedral is the seat of the Bishop of Köln. (Jan. 2008)

One of the monks at the Köln cathedral: his job seemed to be to keep people off the area behind the fence. The kindly soul did permit me to take his picture though. Too bad the file got corrupted (hence the grey band on the left). Oh well, what can one do when technology lets us down? (Jan. 2008)
Another view of the signage in the Köln cathedral crypt which shows the various cardinals bishops and their tenure. The Köln cathedral is the seat of the Bishop of Köln. (Jan. 2008)

A nativity scene diorama was still in place near the Köln cathedral entrance exit. Of course it was barely three weeks past Christmas. A huge crowd had gathered at the spot, hence a hurried grab shot. (Jan. 2008)

That's a self timer shot of moi inside the Köln cathedral. Totally pooped, and with shaky, wobbly legs after the steep 509 step climb up, in freaking cold weather, I simply had to rest. It's a large cathedral, and there is plenty of seating for the devout. Now I'm not a Christian, in fact I'm not even a believer in God, but sitting in that cathedral for about half an hour with eyes closed and shut off to the world did overwhelm me with a sense of peace and calm. (Jan. 2008)
As I emerge from the crupt, I pass another shrine in the Köln cathedral with a lot of candle burning going on. (Jan. 2008)
Another of the impressive stained glass windows of the Köln cathedral, very painstakingly restored. (Jan. 2008)
Another view of the signage showing the various cardinals bishops at the Köln cathedral and the tenure of their service. (Jan. 2008)

The imposing and elegant Cologne Cathedral as approached from Burgmauer (May 2012).

<b>Cologne Cathedral (<i>Kölner Dom<i>) from the <i>Bahnofsvorplatz<i> close to Cologne Central Station (<i>Köln Hauptbahnhof<i>), Germany.<b> Taken on the outward journey for our holiday in Germany (July 2011): London - Köln - Wernigerode (Harz Mountains) - Weimar (Thuringia) - London Official name of the Cathedral is <i>Hohe Domkirche St. Peter und Maria<i> (High Cathedral of Sts. Peter and Mary). It is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Construction began in 1248 but was halted in 1473, leaving it unfinished. Work recommenced in the 19th century and was completed, to the original plan, in 1880. The architectural style is Gothic. Photo shows the N side of the cathedral. Scaffolding is for renovations (apparently renovations are almost continuous). The cathedral is a huge landmark which can be seen from considerable distances. Being just across the square (<i>Bahnhofsvorplatz<i>) from the equally impressive <a href"http:flic.krpd9WWkV" rel"nofollow">Cologne Central Station (<i>Köln Hauptbahnhof<i>) <a>, and close to the huge steel Hohenzollern Bridge (<i>Hohenzollernbrücke<i>), this makes for a striking <a href"http:bit.lyTNrpU9" rel"nofollow">contrast<a> in styles, function and history of three huge structures. For more information about the Cathedral: <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiCologne_Cathedral" rel"nofollow">en.wikipedia.orgwikiCologne_Cathedral<a> <b>Photo<b> Brian © Darkroom Daze <a href"http:bit.ly47tbGf" rel"nofollow">Creative Commons<a>. If you would like to use or refer to this image, please link or attribute. ID: DSC_2113 - Version 2

Cologne Cathedral, Cologne, Germany Cologne Cathedral was built between 1248 and 1880. It is 144.5 metres (474 ft) long, 86.5 m (284 ft) wide and its towers are approximately 157 m (515 ft) tall. The cathedral is the largest Gothic church in Northern Europe and has the second-tallest spire and largest façade of any church in the world. Vertical panorama from 7 horizontal HDR pictures (-2,0,+2). <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiCologne_Cathedral" rel"nofollow">en.wikipedia.orgwikiCologne_Cathedral<a>

The Cologne Cathedral as seen near the Hohenzollern bridge. This almost 800-year old Gothic delight is a World Heritage Site and the most visited landmark in all Germany. Underneath is a shrine which houses what is said to be the remains of the Three Kings.

germany deutschland candles cologne colognecathedral kölner

These people spell each other off at certain intervals. A while back I saw a CSI episode involving a dead living statue who had been propped up until he got a bit ripe. Of course, the case got solved within an hour. This statue is one of the magi. At the high altar stands a reliquary which, allegedly, contains the bones of the magi. The reliquary has featured in the Cathedral since the twelfth century. For this reason, Cologne Cathedral was a destination for pilgrims over a period of centuries.

One of the Cologne Cathedral's gargoyles which are ironically images of the demonic animals and characters, Gargoyles are attached to the gutters of the cathedral to divert rain water as far away from the building as possible. I snapped this image as I climbed the circular 509 steps to the viewing platform which is 322 feet or 98 meters above the ground (May 2012).

<b>Cologne Cathedral (<i>Kölner Dom<i>) from one of the platforms of Cologne Central Station (<i>Köln Hauptbahnhof<i>) looking across <i>Bahnofsvorplatz<i> (Germany).<b> Taken on a very overcast day on a work visit to Bonn (November 2007) whilst changing trains. Official name of the Cathedral is <i>Hohe Domkirche St. Peter und Maria<i> (High Cathedral of Sts. Peter and Mary). It is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Construction began in 1248 but was halted in 1473, leaving it unfinished. Work recommenced in the 19th century and was completed, to the original plan, in 1880. The architectural style is Gothic. The cathedral is a huge landmark which can be seen from considerable distances. Being just across the square (<i>Bahnhofsvorplatz<i>) from the equally impressive <a href"http:flic.krpd9WWkV" rel"nofollow">Cologne Central Station (<i>Köln Hauptbahnhof<i>) <a>, and close to the huge steel Hohenzollern Bridge (<i>Hohenzollernbrücke<i>), this makes for a striking <a href"http:bit.lyTNrpU9" rel"nofollow">contrast<a> in styles, function and history of three huge structures. This view, taken from one of the station platforms across the eastern corner of <i>Bahnhofsvorplatz<i>, shows how close the station is to the N side of the Cathedral. <a href"http:flic.krpd9WWkV" rel"nofollow">Here<a> is the reverse view taken four years later from near where the white vans are parked in front of the Cathedral here. For more information about the Cathedral: <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiCologne_Cathedral" rel"nofollow">en.wikipedia.orgwikiCologne_Cathedral<a> <b>Photo<b> Brian © Darkroom Daze <a href"http:bit.ly47tbGf" rel"nofollow">Creative Commons<a>. If you would like to use or refer to this image, please link or attribute. ID: CIMG0493

<b>North aisle of Cologne Cathedral (<i>Kölner Dom<i>), Germany.<b> Taken on the outward journey for our holiday in Germany (July 2011): London - Köln - Wernigerode (Harz Mountains) - Weimar (Thuringia) - London Official name of the Cathedral is <i>Hohe Domkirche St. Peter und Maria<i> (High Cathedral of Sts. Peter and Mary). It is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Construction began in 1248 but was halted in 1473, leaving it unfinished. Work recommenced in the 19th century and was completed, to the original plan, in 1880. The architectural style is Gothic. For more information about the Cathedral: <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiCologne_Cathedral" rel"nofollow">en.wikipedia.orgwikiCologne_Cathedral<a> The Cathedral generally appears darker inside than this photo shows. <b>On the steps of Cologne Cathedral (<i>Kölner Dom<i>)<b>. Taken on our return rail journey at the end of our holiday. Today we left Bonn on a local train, and changed at Cologne (<i>Köln<i>) where we had a little bit of spare time. We then took an ICE train to Brussels (Bruxelles Midi), Belgium, where we changed to a Eurostar train for St.Pancras International, London. By coincidence, this gave me the chance to photograph (and contrast) the great arched canopies of different ages, of three famous railway stations all in one day - Cologne Central, Liège Guillemins and London St.Pancras. By another coincidence, we found we were due to cross paths at St.Pancras with some of the family on an outward trip to France. We had some time to spare between changing trains at Cologne (<i>Köln<i>) so we sat in the sun, using the Cathedral steps for our waiting room. <b>Photo<b> by Brian (upper), Jill (lower). © Darkroom Daze <a href"http:bit.ly47tbGf" rel"nofollow">Creative Commons<a>. If you would like to use or refer to this image, please link or attribute. ID: DSC_5236-5237 - Version 2

<b>Decorative work on one of the pairs of large bronze doors of Cologne Cathedral (<i>Kölner Dom<i>), Germany.<b> Taken on the outward journey for our holiday in Germany (July 2011): London - Köln - Wernigerode (Harz Mountains) - Weimar (Thuringia) - London Official name of the Cathedral is <i>Hohe Domkirche St. Peter und Maria<i> (High Cathedral of Sts. Peter and Mary). It is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Construction began in 1248 but was halted in 1473, leaving it unfinished. Work recommenced in the 19th century and was completed, to the original plan, in 1880. The architectural style is Gothic. For more information about the Cathedral: <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiCologne_Cathedral" rel"nofollow">en.wikipedia.orgwikiCologne_Cathedral<a> From memory, I think this set of doors is at the western end of the Cathedral. I have not yet been able to find out any useful historical or art details about any of the bronze doors of the Cathedral. Just guessing that they are 19th Century in Medieval style? The clothing of the figures and the musical instruments they are playing seem to be late Medieval - L-R: bagpipe, rattles, fiddle and a double trumpet, like a Medieval equivalent of a rock band, I guess. The lions don't look too happy. I guess the band was making too much of a racket, and perhaps the lions were contemplating eating the musicians for supper. <b>Photo<b> Brian © Darkroom Daze <a href"http:bit.ly47tbGf" rel"nofollow">Creative Commons<a>. If you would like to use or refer to this image, please link or attribute. ID: DSC_2117 - Version 2

The rally that was being set up got underway while I was climbing down the tower. There were a lot of police keeping their distance. My best guess at what the rally was about came from a sign (in another photo) that seems to be asking if 2009 will mark the end of Christianity in Turkey. Allow me to claim ignorance of who organized this rally and why -- I just happened to be there so took a few pictures.

Rainald of Dassel (c. 1120 – August 14, 1167 near Rome) was archbishop of Cologne from 1159 to 1167 and archchancellor of Italy He had an amazing and daring career. One of many military clerics of the middle ages. <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiRainald_of_Dassel">en.wikipedia.orgwikiRainald_of_Dassel<a>

This stained glass window in Cologne Cathedral really surprised me; it justaposes strongly with all the other - traditional - windows. Consisting only of different coloured dots, it reminds me of pixels and makes me think of a 'technology' themed church.

24 June 2006 The sign on the cathedral door says, "Rosenkranzgebet und Abendmesse sind wegen der WM nach St. Maria - Himmelfahrt verlegt! Der Dom bleibt geschlossen!" Roughly, I think this means: "Rosaries and evening mass are delayed (cancelled?) for the World Cup match (and) the Virgin Mary has gone on a trip to heaven. The cathedral is closed."
june germany deutschland juin football europa europe fussball cathedral fifa cologne köln 2006 worldcup celesteh
24 June 2006 Tourists from all over the world and Germans lingered in the square in front of the cathedral. A common bond of football love tied them together.

Statue of Archangel Michael with traditional shield bearing the inscription 'quis ut deus' ('Who is like God?') I love random details in churches... I really think the person that's being stood on (or killed? Going deaf? Suffering from neck pain?) looks more Mayan than Gothic.

<b><i>Köln Hauptbahnhof<i> (Cologne Central Station, Germany) - one of Europe's great railway stations.<b> Selected shot from our return rail journey at the end of our holiday. Today we left Bonn on a local train, and changed at Cologne (<i>Köln<i>) where we had a little bit of spare time. We then took an ICE train to Brussels (Bruxelles Midi), Belgium, where we changed to a Eurostar train for St.Pancras International, London. By coincidence, this gave me the chance to photograph (and contrast) the great arched canopies of different ages, of three famous railway stations all in one day - Cologne Central, Liège Guillemins and London St.Pancras. By another coincidence, we found we were due to cross paths at St.Pancras with some of the family on an outward trip to France. This station is an important rail hub for Germany and for this part of Europe. The main arched canopy is out of sight away to the L. This smaller canopy is relatively modern, built to cover platform extensions. In the distance is the massive <i>Hohenzollernbrücke<i> (Hohenzollern Bridge), which carries the main railway lines over the River Rhine. Remarkably, this station and bridge are adjacent to the huge medieval cathedral of Cologne (out of sight here, behind us) and make a striking contrast of styles, function and history. This view was taken from near the top of the cathedral steps, looking E at the SE end of the station. In the foreground is a high speed ICE train of Deutsche Bahn (German Railways) and the red train further away, partly on the bridge, is a local train. THE BRIDGE The <i>Hohenzollernbrücke<i> (Hohenzollern Bridge) was constructed between 1907 and 1911 after the old bridge, the <i>Dombrücke<i> (Cathedral Bridge) was demolished. It consists of multiple bow-string cantilevers. This was one of the most important bridges in Germany during World War II but German military engineers blew up the bridge when Allied troops began their assault on Cologne. Three years later, the Hohenzollern Bridge was accessible to pedestrians again and full usage was restored by 1959. Today, more than 1200 trains a day use the Hohenzollern Bridge - the highest usage of any rail bridge in Germany. Source: <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiHohenzollern_Bridge" rel"nofollow">en.wikipedia.orgwikiHohenzollern_Bridge<a> THE TRAINS The nearer train is a high speed train of the German railway system, <i>Deutsche Bahn<i>. According to the <a href"http:www.eurail.complanningtrains-and-ferrieshigh-speed-trainsice" rel"nofollow">Eurail website<a>, "With a maximum speed of 300 kmh (186 mph) these high-speed trains connect major German cities at hourly intervals. International ICE trains connect Germany with Austria (Wien, Innsbruck), Belgium (Brussels, Liège), Denmark (Copenhagen, Arhus), France (Paris), the Netherlands (Arnhem, Utrecht, Amsterdam) and Switzerland (Zürich, Interlaken)." Although the trains are a German service and brand, ICE stands for 'Inter-City Express' in English. The red train in the distance belongs to the Rhine-Ruhr S-Bahn (<i>S-Bahn Rhein-Ruhr<i>), a local and regional rail network covering the Rhine-Ruhr Metropolitan Region. <b>Photo<b> Brian © Darkroom Daze <a href"http:bit.ly47tbGf" rel"nofollow">Creative Commons<a>. If you would like to use or refer to this image, please link or attribute. ID: DSC_5233 - Version 2

<b><i>Köln Hauptbahnhof<i> (Cologne Central Station, Germany) - one of Europe's great railway stations.<b> Selected shot from our return rail journey at the end of our holiday. Today we left Bonn on a local train, and changed at Cologne (<i>Köln<i>) where we had a little bit of spare time. We then took an ICE train to Brussels (Bruxelles Midi), Belgium, where we changed to a Eurostar train for St.Pancras International, London. By coincidence, this gave me the chance to photograph (and contrast) the great arched canopies of different ages, of three famous railway stations all in one day - Cologne Central, Liège Guillemins and London St.Pancras. By another coincidence, we found we were due to cross paths at St.Pancras with some of the family on an outward trip to France. This station is an important rail hub for Germany and for this part of Europe. The main arched canopy in the L background dates back to 1894 though subsequently rebuilt. The nearer canopy is relatively modern, built to cover platform extensions, and blending well with the main arch. Remarkably, this station is adjacent to the huge medieval cathedral of Cologne (out of sight here behind us) and makes a striking contrast of styles, function and history. This view was taken from near the top of the cathedral steps, looking NE at the SE end of the station. <a href"http:flic.krpdauMzp" rel"nofollow">Here<a> is the reverse view. <b>Photo<b> Brian © Darkroom Daze <a href"http:bit.ly47tbGf" rel"nofollow">Creative Commons<a>. If you would like to use or refer to this image, please link or attribute. ID: DSC_5226 - Version 2

<b>Our ICE train for Brussels Midi (Belgium) pulls into <i>Köln Hauptbahnhof<i> (Cologne Central Station, Germany) - one of Europe's great railway stations.<b> Selected shot from our return rail journey at the end of our holiday. Today we left Bonn on a local train, and changed at Cologne (<i>Köln<i>) where we had a little bit of spare time. We then took an ICE train to Brussels (Bruxelles Midi), Belgium, where we changed to a Eurostar train for St.Pancras International, London. By coincidence, this gave me the chance to photograph (and contrast) the great arched canopies of different ages, of three famous railway stations all in one day - Cologne Central, Liège Guillemins and London St.Pancras. By another coincidence, we found we were due to cross paths at St.Pancras with some of the family on an outward trip to France. This station is an important rail hub for Germany and for this part of Europe. Above the train is the main arched canopy of the station which dates back to 1894 though subsequently rebuilt. The big advert (<i>4711 Echt Kölnisch Wasser<i>) is for the internationally well known local brand of 'eau de toilette' (perfumed water) known better to most English speakers by its French name <i>Eau de Cologne<i>. Remarkably, this station is adjacent to the huge medieval cathedral of Cologne (out of sight here, away to the R) and makes a striking contrast of styles, function and history. This view showstrain approaching from the SE end of the station. <b>THE TRAIN<b> According to the <a href"http:www.eurail.complanningtrains-and-ferrieshigh-speed-trainsice" rel"nofollow">Eurail website<a>, "With a maximum speed of 300 kmh (186 mph) these high-speed trains connect major German cities at hourly intervals. International ICE trains connect Germany with Austria (Wien, Innsbruck), Belgium (Brussels, Liège), Denmark (Copenhagen, Arhus), France (Paris), the Netherlands (Arnhem, Utrecht, Amsterdam) and Switzerland (Zürich, Interlaken)." Although the trains are a German service and brand, ICE stands for 'Inter-City Express' in English. This set (Tz 4607) bears the city name <i>Hannover<i> and is a third generation ICE (SeriesBaureihe ICE 3M : Siemens Velaro D, German Railway Class 407). This train is arriving from Frankfurt for the 11:43 departure for Brussels (Bruxelles Midi), Belgium). We had seen the <a href"http:flic.krpdkkzNm" rel"nofollow">same set<a> a year before on the counterpart service to Frankfurt, as it passed through Liège-Guillemins station in Belgium. <b>Photo<b> Brian © Darkroom Daze <a href"http:bit.ly47tbGf" rel"nofollow">Creative Commons<a>. If you would like to use or refer to this image, please link or attribute. ID: DSC_5242 - Version 2

railroad roof building station electric train germany deutschland track gare platform cologne eisenbahn rail railway zug bahnhof köln db advertisement railwaystation trainstation advert emu deutschebahn canopy bahn stazione quai icetrain nordrheinwestfalen coaches streamline catenary gleis railroadstation kölnischwasser estacióndetren chemindefer highspeedtrain colognecentralstation eaudecologne electricmultipleunit kölnhauptbahnhof standardgauge ice3m electricmotorunit 1435mmgauge

<b><i>Köln Hauptbahnhof<i> (Cologne Central Station, Germany) - one of Europe's great railway stations.<b> Selected shot from our return rail journey at the end of our holiday. Today we left Bonn on a local train, and changed at Cologne (<i>Köln<i>) where we had a little bit of spare time. We then took an ICE train to Brussels (Bruxelles Midi), Belgium, where we changed to a Eurostar train for St.Pancras International, London. By coincidence, this gave me the chance to photograph (and contrast) the great arched canopies of different ages, of three famous railway stations all in one day - Cologne Central, Liège Guillemins and London St.Pancras. By another coincidence, we found we were due to cross paths at St.Pancras with some of the family on an outward trip to France. This station is an important rail hub for Germany and for this part of Europe. The main arched canopy in the L background dates back to 1894 though subsequently rebuilt. The nearer canopy is relatively modern, built to cover platform extensions, and blending well with the main arch. Remarkably, this station is adjacent to the huge medieval cathedral of Cologne (out of sight here behind us) and makes a striking contrast of styles, function and history. This view was taken from near the top of the cathedral steps, looking at the SE end of the station. <b>Photo<b> Brian © Darkroom Daze <a href"http:bit.ly47tbGf" rel"nofollow">Creative Commons<a>. If you would like to use or refer to this image, please link or attribute. ID: DSC_5227 - Version 2

<b><i>Köln Hauptbahnhof<i> (Cologne Central Station, Germany) - one of Europe's great railway stations.<b> Selected shot from our return rail journey at the end of our holiday. Today we left Bonn on a local train, and changed at Cologne (<i>Köln<i>) where we had a little bit of spare time. We then took an ICE train to Brussels (Bruxelles Midi), Belgium, where we changed to a Eurostar train for St.Pancras International, London. By coincidence, this gave me the chance to photograph (and contrast) the great arched canopies of different ages, of three famous railway stations all in one day - Cologne Central, Liège Guillemins and London St.Pancras. By another coincidence, we found we were due to cross paths at St.Pancras with some of the family on an outward trip to France. This station is an important rail hub for Germany and for this part of Europe. This is the main arched canopy which dates back to 1894 though subsequently rebuilt. A lower, more recent extension canopy can be seen in the distance. The advert (<i>4711 Echt Kölnisch Wasser<i>) is for the internationally well known local brand of 'eau de toilette' (perfumed water) known better to most English speakers by its French name <i>Eau de Cologne<i>. Remarkably, this station is adjacent to the huge medieval cathedral of Cologne (out of sight here, away to the R) and makes a striking contrast of styles, function and history. This view shows the SE end of the station. <b>Photo<b> Brian © Darkroom Daze <a href"http:bit.ly47tbGf" rel"nofollow">Creative Commons<a>. If you would like to use or refer to this image, please link or attribute. ID: DSC_5240 - Version 2

<b><i>Köln Hauptbahnhof<i> (Cologne Central Station, Germany) - one of Europe's great railway stations.<b> Taken on the outward journey for our holiday in Germany (July 2011): London - Köln - Wernigerode (Harz Mountains) - Weimar (Thuringia) - London This station is an important rail hub for Germany and for this part of Europe. This view is taken from the window of the Ibis hotel, which is integral with the station frontage on the western side of the station. The inner side of the hotel overlooks the station platforms like this with a side view across the main platform area under the great arched canopy. The canopy arches can just be seen through the upper windows in this view. The canopy dates back to 1894 though subsequently rebuilt. Remarkably, this station is adjacent to the huge medieval cathedral of Cologne (out of sight here, away to the R) and makes a striking contrast of styles, function and history. The two trains consist of duplex (double-decker) carriages, on local services. <b>Photo<b> Brian © Darkroom Daze <a href"http:bit.ly47tbGf" rel"nofollow">Creative Commons<a>. If you would like to use or refer to this image, please link or attribute. ID: DSC_2118 - Version 2
